div.l: How that begiled was a Carpynter
ꝐPerauenture in scorn̄ For y am oon̄
And bi youre lefe y schal hym quite anon̄
Right in his Chorles t̉ermes wol y speke
I pray to god his necke mote to breke
He can wel in myn eye se a stalke
But in his own̄ he can not se a balke
Hic incipit fabula p̉repositiFabula p̉repositi
¶ Att Trumpyngton̄ not fer fro Cambrigge
Þer goth a brook and ouer þat a brigge
Vpon þe which bl bl brook þer standith a mylle
And þis is verrey soth þat y you telle
A Miller was þer dwellyng many a day
As any Pecok he was prowde and gay
Pipe he cowde / and Fysshe and nettes bete
And turne Cuppes ⁊and well wrastle and lepe
And by his belt he bare a longe Panade
Of a swerde full trenchant was þe blade
A ioly popper bare he in his pouche
Þer was no man̄ for parell durste hym touche
A Sheffeld twytel bare he in his pouche hosepouchehose
Rounde was his face ⁊and camwsed was his nose
As piled as an ape was his skulle
He was a markett beter / att þe fulle
Þer durst no wight hand on hym legge
But he d d swore anon he sholde abegge
A thefe he was for soth of Corn ⁊and mele
And þat a slye / and vsaunt for to stele
His name was called deignous Symkyn̄
A wife he hadde Comen of noble kyn̄
The Person̄ of þe Toun̄ here fader was
Wᵗith hire he yafe ful many a panne of bras
For þat Symkyn̄ sholde / in his blood a lye
Sche was fostred in a Nonnerye
For Symkyn̄ wold no wife / as he saide
But sche were wele norisshed // ⁊and a a a mayde
To safe his estate of yomanrye
And sche was proude ⁊and pert as a pye
A ful faire sight it was / vpon hem twoo
On halidayes afore here wolde he doo goodoogoo
Wᵗith his tepet wounde aboute his heed
And sche came aftir hym in a gite of reed
And Symkyn̄ hadde hosyn̄ of the same
Þer durste no wight clepe here but dame
Was noon so hardy þat went bi the way
Þat with here durst rage oþer play
But if he wolde be slayn̄ of Symkyn̄
Wᵗith Panade his knyfe or wᵗith boydekyn̄
For ielous folk ben perilous euer moo
All gate þei wolde þᵗat here wifes wend soo
And eke for sche was somdele smotherlyche
Sche was as deignous / as water in a dyche
